Can it avoid the fate of Wal-Mart Express? Jeremy Bowman (TMFHobo) Oct 7, 2016 at 7:08PM Image Source: Motley Fool.¬† With a resurgent¬†Wal-Mart¬†(NYSE:WMT)¬†and¬†Amazon.com¬†growing faster than ever, Target¬†(NYSE:TGT) is getting squeezed in the middle. Comparable sales turned negative in its most recent quarter, falling 1.1%, reflecting a trend throughout retail as department store chains struggle across the board.¬† E-commerce sales growth is also losing steam. Though digital sales grew 16% in the second quarter, that was down from 23% in the previous quarter, and, more importantly, the company lowered its forecast for the rest of the year. It now sees comps from flat to down 2% in the third and fourth quarters, which includes the key holiday season. ¬† Thinking small The discount retailer is turning to a familiar strategy to stem sliding sales. It's looking to open smaller-footprint locations in densely packed cities and college towns. Other retailers, including¬†Nordstrom,¬†Whole Foods,¬†Macy's, and¬†Wal-Mart,¬†have looked to smaller stores to expand their footprint and beef up sales. Target is opening up a slate of smaller stores in big cities and college towns in order to cater to the millennials that make up one of its core constituencies. This week it opened a 45,000 square-foot store in New York's Tribeca neighborhood, about a third of the size of the average Target.¬†Near the University of Minnesota campus, a store 15% the size of a regular Target stocks items intended for college students like mini ironing boards and twin sheets. CEO Brian Cornell told¬†The Wall Street Journal, "We could see hundreds of these. It could be a huge part of future growth outlook over time."¬† In many ways, the small-footprint strategy fits well with Cornell's emphasis on signature categories, including health and wellness, baby and kids, stylish apparel and home goods. Those are all categories that millennials care about, and as young people have flocked to cities it makes sense for Target to follow them. Currently, those customers are driving Amazon's growth, as no major brick-and-mortar chain has made a play for them.¬† Avoiding Wal-Mart's fate At the beginning of the year, Wal-Mart announced it would shut down all 102 of its Walmart Express stores, a small-footprint concept scattered across the rural south, just a few years after launching the miniaturized chain. The Express stores faced several challenges. Wal-Mart struggled to get the product mix right, as operating small stores entails more than simply shrinking the Supercenters. It also opened many of them near existing Wal-Marts, obviating much of the need for a smaller version. ¬† But Target's more upscale brand should give it an advantage, as should its focus on cities and college towns, places where shoppers may not have cars and therefore need convenient options close to home. Many of those cities are also devoid of Wal-Mart, as the retail giant has found it difficult to penetrate many of the nation's largest cities and is still without a store in New York. Instead of imitating Wal-Mart, Target may be better off following the lead of drugstores chain like¬†Walgreen's¬†and¬†CVS, its new pharmacy partner, as that category has seen steady growth, with sales at health and personal care stores up 7.7% this year according to the Census Bureau.¬†Sales at those stores have not only benefited from their selling more prescriptions, but they have also stocked more groceries, and consumers have turned to them for convenient "fill-in" trips. Target has to do more than just be a drugstore to make the small-store experiment work, but with its "cheap chic" brand it should be able to find the right mix between its signature categories and everyday staples like groceries and household items. While small stores could provide a valuable new revenue stream, it won't flip Target's sales slide overnight, as the company's most pressing problem is reinvigorating performance at 1,800 big-box stores. Grocery sales have been a problem,¬†as the company has seen more spoilage than its competitors, and accelerating e-commerce growth would also be a promising sign. Still, with comparable sales headed negative for the rest of the year, the retailer could use some good news in the form of successful small stores to tout to investors. Jeremy Bowman has no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool has no position in any of the stocks mentioned. Try any of our Foolish newsletter services free for 30 days. We Fools may not all hold the same opinions, but we all believe that considering a diverse range of insights makes us better investors. The Motley Fool has a disclosure policy. Author Jeremy Bowman (TMFHobo) Fool since 2011. I write about consumer goods, the big picture, and whatever else piques my interest. Follow me on Twitter to see my latest articles, and for commentary on hot topics in retail and the broad market. Channels ¬†Music ¬†Style ¬†Pop Culture ¬†Sports ¬†Sneakers ¬†Life ¬†Videos ¬†Election 2016 ¬†Shop; Our Sites ¬†First We Feast ¬†Pigeons & Planes ¬†Collider ¬†Sole Collector ¬†Green Label ¬†Ride Channel; Life Life NSFW Video Shows Brawl Breaking Out at Florida Walmart During Hurricane Matthew Panic Share Tweet NSFW Video Shows Brawl Breaking Out at Florida Walmart During Hurricane Matthew Panic By Trace William Cowen happy to waste more of your time here:¬†@tracecowen Oct 07, 2016 Share Tweet 0 Subscribe to Complex Video via YouTube A full-on fight broke out between two customers at a South Florida Walmart Thursday, just as Hurricane Matthew had residents stocking up on household essentials in preparation for possible power outages. Video of the incident was first shared on Facebook Thursday afternoon before being removed, according to the Miami Herald. Hurricane Matthew vs Miami pic.twitter.com/w8wbQ2cl4F ‚Äî #LongLiveFlee (@_RedRum) October 6, 2016 Related Texas Pool Party Flips Into Royal Rumble Real Quick Trash Cans Fly, Baseball Bats Swing in 30-Person Wal-Mart Brawl Everything We Know About Hurricane Matthew In the slightly NSFW footage, two unidentified women are seen screaming, throwing punches, and pulling each other's hair. One woman then hits another woman with a shopping cart, at which point canned food items are tossed around. The original caption on the Facebook version of the video claimed the two Walmart customers were fighting over "the last case of water," but an anonymous Walmart employee told the Herald they were disputing their place in the checkout line. Hurricane Matthew vs Miami pt2 pic.twitter.com/ypPTY8vquh ‚Äî #LongLiveFlee (@_RedRum) October 6, 2016 Hurricane warnings were still in effect from Cocoa Beach, Florida to Surf City, North Carolina at the time of publication. According to the Weather Channel, "potentially serious" flooding may impact areas in Georgia, South Carolina, and southern parts of North Carolina through Saturday night. Flooding had already occurred along the Florida coast, including spots near Jacksonville Beach and Daytona Beach. Hurricane Matthew has caused major disruptions in retail stores across Florida, with Reuters reporting Friday that many Walmart locations had closed due to the storm: "A spokesperson said the company was using its experience of past disasters to anticipate what goods may be in greater demand after the storm passes." SB Nation Login Sign Up Niners Nation, a San Francisco 49ers community Home Fanposts Fanshots Sections 49ers Press Conferences & Conference Calls 49ers Injury News 49ers Transactions Levi's Stadium Events 49ers Salary Cap Full Archive Library 49ers Salary Cap¬†2017 49ers Salary Cap¬†2016 2016-2017 NFL calendar: League year, free agency, draft, salary cap¬†deadlines NFL mock draft database 2016 - 49ers picks across the¬†Internet 49ers Stories Schedule Roster Stats Yahoo 49ers News Yahoo 49ers Team Page Yahoo 49ers Report Yahoo 49ers Depth Chart Yahoo 49ers Transactions Yahoo 49ers Photos StubHub Odds Shop About Masthead Community Guidelines More NFL NBA MLB NHL CFB Recruiting CBB UFC Soccer NASCAR Fantasy Golf Shop StubHub Radio Tennis Cycling Boxing Horse Racing Podcasts Local Running Wrestling Outsports Video Odds More SB Nation All 317 blogs Ôòê Ôòë üîéSearch Search Ó¶° Fanshots Fanposts FanPost 49ers‚Äô Quest for Continuity: The Queen of Hearts, Walmart and¬†Vision By Reasonable Opinion on Oct 7, 2016, 1:53pm PDT 24 Tweet Share Ôòë Tweet Share on Twitter ÔòêShare Share on Facebook ÔôêPin Pinterest 24 Comments ‚ãÜ Rec Recommend this Post 1 In Lewis Carroll‚Äôs Alice, the foul-mouthed Queen of Hearts solves the problems of her realm by screeching: "Off with their heads!" If you watched the first five games of this new-era-49er season you might be tempted to do the same. One notable quirk about the Queen of Hearts is that her commands were routinely ignored. No one was ever executed. So it will be for the folks on this blog who keep demanding the termination of this or that person in the 49ers hierarchy. The truth is that no one gets fired in York-land unless there is a sufficient breach in operational tranquility at 4949 Centennial (as there was with Jim Harbaugh) or in the abject event that the team wins less than a handful of games over a couple of years under a new, seemingly competent head coach. Barring such an eventuality, our only realistic hope for continuity in this franchise is from working within the status quo. It is therefore important to understand what the status quo actually is. Continuity and good coaching are essential ingredients to success in team sports. Letting players adjust to a good and flexible scheme, play faster and make fewer mistakes through repetition lifts the aggregate performance just as much as the infusion of talent. But the rate of influx and departure of talent is also an important variable largely independent of the first two, influenced as it is by the culture from the top of the organization. For example, the culture may determine what resources are allocated to scouting and re-signing homegrown talent, or for acquiring expensive free agents. Thus, it is important to understand the tension between a head coach‚Äôs vision and the owner‚Äôs fiscal policies, as these are at the core of the crucible within which continuity must be forged if the franchise is ever to experience success. I think we are now in the early stages of a phase in the franchise‚Äôs history that could just as easily turn out well as go down in flames. In the midst of such fragility it is sometimes easy to lose sight of context and keep shouting ‚Äòoff with their heads‚Äô. I will try and describe the context I see. Fans who impersonate the Queen of Hearts when faced with employees like Baalke, Marathe and even Jed often miss the fact that these men are simply extensions of a philosophy that originates at the very top: Daddy York. That philosophy is, fundamentally, a Walmart philosophy completely devoid of football vision but thoroughly imbued with a desire to maximize shareholder value. Indeed the only big ‚Äòwin‚Äô the Yorks have experienced in the nearly two decades since they acquired operational control of the team is the building of a stadium that made the 49ers franchise one of the five most valuable in the sport. That‚Äôs something they care about. To understand the pedantic mind of a John York, go back to his public comments in 2000 when he dismantled the continuity of a proud franchise in order to ‚Äòsave money‚Äô. Nothing illustrates this better than the way he squandered cost-effective Pro-Bowl linemen like Derrick Deese (LT) and Kevin Gogan (RG) who, at the time, cost us 1.1 and 2.3 million annually, good deals even back then. If that period and the years of mediocrity that followed do not convince you, go back to the seventies. John, the young pathologist, spent an epic seven years as a postdoc trying to land a real job in academia, but without success. In science, seven-year post-doctoral stints are exceedingly rare and can mean only one thing ‚Äî though, to his credit, John York eventually turned a smart trick and married into money. Which is why Daddy York and his pedantic mind can now direct our team‚Äôs fate from his dinner table as chief shareholder. Understand the man and you will instantly understand why Paraag Marathe is so loved by the Yorks for being ‚Äòshrewd‚Äô with player contracts, and why Baalke stocks up on late picks, scanning the boroughs for talent bargains each cycle ‚Äî busted ACLs presenting no particular obstacle. It‚Äôs like shopping at Walmart. It would not be hard to imagine Daddy York vetoing the deal Baalke put together in Denver after Harbaugh‚Äôs dismissal ‚Äî one that might have retained some continuity with Fangio while upgrading the offensive vision with Gase. Instead Daddy may have preferred the cheaper Tomsula option. Penny pinchers without vision make uninspired choices like this all the time. I know people who fit that mold. Their backyards are filled with rusted things that no longer work; though, at the time they were bought, those items were such a deal. Vision, on the other hand, is a rare thing to find in a head coach. After Walsh, we had to wait decades for Kelly. There is nothing more frustrating for a coach with vision and creativity than working for bosses without it. I know exactly how it feels. Kelly‚Äôs leverage is compromised by recent history, so he has to keep mum and suffer. For now. Having said all this, if there is a time to Walmart the team it is certainly this season, and I think Kelly must understand that too. In order to build continuity, there must first be something worth continuing. You can‚Äôt buy more than a handful of players in an offseason, anyway. The rest must come from those you draft over several years. Baalke did indeed draft a bunch of young guys, but their evaluation by Tomsula‚Äôs staff is not definitive ‚Äî in part because Kelly‚Äôs system requires different skill sets (for example, zone blocking). Until the current staff knows who the ‚Äòkeepers‚Äô are, it is hard to decide where to spend one‚Äôs offseason capital. The 49ers certainly have the cap so it is mostly a matter of knowing what to buy, even if one shops at Walmart. The key part of offensive continuity, which (in my view) is much harder to build than defensive continuity, is a franchise quarterback. The 49ers do not have such a player on their roster. Baalke has invested just one top-100 pick (Kaepernick) on a QB since the Ice Age. However, since it takes a couple of years for linemen and journeymen skill players to get their timing down in a new offense, it may make sense to draft a QB only after some semblance of stability has been built around that position (see: running game, pass pro). In the meantime, Alex Smith 2.0 would be fine as placeholder, and I think Kelly is trying to make Gabbert into that; though, so far, not successfully. So how should we see this dynamic tension between Kelly‚Äôs vision and Walmart in our quest to build continuity on the 49ers? What‚Äôs in the crystal ball? Here‚Äôs my guess, and it is only a guess: 1. More Gabbert (with a possible detour to Kaep). Gabbert helps prepare the team in practice with good and accurate execution, I understand, even if he does seem to beg a psychiatrist during games. (Blaine should talk to John Smoltz ‚Äî what an inflexion point his sports psychiatrist was in 1991, both for Smoltz and the Braves!) With Garnett in there perhaps the run game will finally get traction, though Tiller is probably more solid in pass pro. Perhaps they can alternate and find out about both phases of the offensive game in alternating series. The play design that Kelly brings is clearly superior to what we‚Äôve seen here in a while. Unfortunately, the execution is still very far behind, like teaching a teenager to gearshift on a Porsche. Until it catches up, Kelly cannot learn what plays of his current repertoire the NFL might have difficulty defending. BTW, If Kilgore goes down, one should note, the offensive experiment is probably lost entirely. Baalke failed to sign a free agent backup center, which I believe should have been a priority last offseason. 2. The defense will continue to bleed run yards, though I‚Äôm holding out some hope for Glen Dorsey (the only almost-healthy NFL-caliber NT on the roster). Not much hope, though. The ILB core was thin to begin with, they drafted no one, they signed no free agents, and they have now lost both starters to injury. There is zero NFL talent left at the ILB position and we will pay for it on run defense. But I was happy to see the emergence of Ray-Ray before his injury. He‚Äôs definitely a keeper. 3. The defense is finding some gems in pass defense, notably Rashard Robinson and Jimmie Ward, but I am also excited for Blair, Buckner, Redmond and Armstead to come into their own, especially now that Lynch is back. It takes a year for a DL to get NFL-wise, anyway. I watch the games now for flashes of promise for next year. All in all, counting IR, I see 14-15 ‚Äòkeepers‚Äô on defense: Buckner, Armstead, Blair, Dial, Williams, Ward, Tartt, Reid, Brock, Reaser, Robinson, Bowman, Ray-Ray, Lynch, possibly Redmond. That is definitely the core of something worth continuing! 4. The receiving corps (TE and WR) is not a source of joy yet, but this may change as the OL improves, which it will. I had hoped that MacDonald would emerge, but he keeps getting hurt. Kerley is a ‚Äòkeeper‚Äô, I think. I reckon the bulk of the free agent dollars we Walmart this coming offseason could well be on WRs. 5. ‚ÄòKeepers‚Äô on offense seem few: Hyde, Staley, Trent Brown, Tiller, Kilgore, Kerley, Torrey Smith, possibly Macdonald and Garnett (7-9). And let‚Äôs not forget Pinion/Nelson on ST. All told, I see a core of 23-27 core players so far. It‚Äôs a start. We need another 6-8 ‚Äòkeepers‚Äô on offense, 3-4 on defense and a kicker. A good fraction of those missing parts could arrive in free agency and the draft this offseason. As for backups, I think we have plenty of those already. One last thought: So long as Chip Kelly gets the pieces he needs to implement his vision does he even care whether or not they were bought at Walmart? This is a FanPost and does not necessarily reflect the views of Niners Nation's writers or editors. It does reflect the views of this particular fan though, which is as important as the views of Niners Nation's writers or editors. The footage, reported to have been filmed inside a Walmart, show the pair punching each other in front of horrified shoppers. 4 The two women were filmed taking part in a brutal fist fight inside the Walmart store 4 Both women punched one another during the shocking fight over the last bottle of water 4 Bystanders were powerless to break up the vicious brawl Taken¬†in Florida, it is believed to have occurred while residents were stocking up for supplies ahead of the storm. One woman, much larger than her opponent, is seen hold her adversary by the hair as she repeatedly uppercuts her. related stories 'THE WORST IS YET TO COME' Hurricane Matthew predicted to bring 12-foot storm surges as it moves to northern states FIRST FATALITIES IN FLORIDA Hurricane Matthew live - path, tracking map and all the latest updates as it barrels into the US HONEYMOON FROM HELL Newlyweds film Bahamas hotel room being destroyed by Hurricane Matthew THE MAGIC GOES OUT at disney Hurricane Matthew forces Disney World to close for first time in 11 years ‚ÄòYour kids are going to die‚Äô Fox news anchor issues warning to Florida residents as Hurricane Matthew approaches 'He has returned' Tragic gorilla Harambe appears in images of Hurricane Matthew and people think it's a 'bad omen' A man nearby tries to intervene ‚Äì but is unable to break up the pair. Although the pair are momentarily¬†pulled¬†apart, the fight continues when the smaller woman, wearing a purple dress, hits her opponent with her handbag. She is then punched several times again before a trolley is rammed into her side. It only ends when she responds by backing away and throwing store items at her opponent, who gives up the chase and walks¬†back to her trolley. Hurricane Matthew is the most powerful storm to hit the US Atlantic Coast in more than a decade. Ëá™Áî±ÈõªÂ≠êÂ†± | ÂΩ±Èü≥Â®õÊ®Ç | Â•ΩÂ∫∑Â†±Â†± | Ëá™Áî±ÈÉ®ËêΩ ‚ÄßBusiness Home Front Page Taiwan News Business Editorials Sports World News Features Bilingual Pages Home / Business Sat, Oct 08, 2016 - Page 10„ÄÄNews List Print Mail Facebook Twitter plurk funp World Business Quick Take Agencies CHEMICALS Total sells Atotech Total SA agreed to sell its specialty chemicals unit Atotech to Carlyle Group LP for US$3.2 billion as the French oil company disposes of non-core assets to weather a slump in crude and preserve payouts to shareholders. The sale price is 11.9 times Atotech‚Äôs adjusted earnings for last year before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization, the companies said in a statement yesterday. Equity for the transaction is to come from buyout funds Carlyle Europe Partners IV and Carlyle Partners VI. Atotech, which had revenue of 1 billion euros (US$1.1 billion) last year, has more than 4,000 employees, mainly in China and Germany. RETAIL Wal-Mart sees flat earnings US retail giant Wal-Mart Stores Inc on Thursday predicted that earnings would be flat in fiscal year 2018 as it pumps up investment in e-commerce initiatives. Wal-Mart said earnings for the next fiscal year that begins on Feb. 1 next year will be essentially unchanged from those of fiscal 2017, which are expected to come in at US$4.15 to US$4.35 a share. The company forecasted an overall capital budget of US$11 billion in both fiscal 2017 and 2018, down from US$11.5 billion in fiscal 2016. It will open 130 new stores in the US in the current year, down from a prior plan to build 135 to 155 stores. The company expects to build 55 new stores in the US in fiscal 2018. INVESTMENT Norwegian fund posts profit Norway‚Äôs US$882 billion sovereign wealth fund, the world‚Äôs biggest, returned a profit in the third quarter thanks to strong stock markets, it said yesterday. The fund earned a return of 4 percent in the quarter, or 240 billion Norwegian kroner (US$29.7 billion), beating its benchmark by 0.2 percentage points. In the second quarter the fund booked a profit of 1.3 percent. ‚ÄúEquity investments performed strongest during the quarter with positive returns in all regions. This was the main contributor to the fund‚Äôs results,‚Äù fund deputy chief executive Trond Grande said in a statement. AVIATION CIT sells leasing unit The CIT Group, a commercial lender, on Thursday agreed to sell its aircraft leasing business to a Chinese-owned competitor for about US$10 billion, signifying a big step by CIT to slim itself down in the face of pressure from investors. CIT is selling its aircraft leasing unit ‚Äî which owns and manages 334 planes and has an additional 133 on order ‚Äî to Avolon Holdings Ltd, which is based in Ireland, but is owned by the HNA Group (Êµ∑Ëà™ÈõÜÂúò) of China. CIT will use the proceeds to pay out more than US$3 billion to its shareholders and to further bolster its balance sheet. RETAIL Seven & i restructuring Seven & i Holdings Co unveiled a restructuring plan to divest struggling department stores and set up a real-estate division, in a bid to focus on boosting profit at its core 7-Eleven business. The new unit, to be created this fiscal year, will explore redeveloping property occupied by under-performing general merchandise stores into housing for seniors or other residential and commercial facilities, company president Ryuichi Isaka said on Thursday. Seven & i also announced a capital alliance with a local retailer and is to transfer three Sogo & Seibu department stores to the partner. Seven & i Holdings shares yesterday fell the most in three months in Tokyo trading in the wake of the plan‚Äôs announcement. This story has been viewed 1240 times. Comments will be moderated. Remarks containing abusive and obscene language, personal attacks of any kind or promotion will be removed and the user banned. Please use a supported version for the best MSN experience. Stock Market Showdown: Target vs. Wal-Mart U.S. News & World Report - Money 10/5/2016 Lou Carlozo ¬© (Getty Images) Which mega retailer will come out on top? Though the shelves at your local Target Corporation (TGT) and Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (WMT) may be stocked well, you still won't find any stock on those shelves ‚Äì not the kind that makes investors wealthy, anyway. Popular Searches Hills Ltd HIL ‚ñº 0.4600 -0.1300 -22.03% Nordex SE NRDXF ‚ñº 19.77 -0.59 -2.90% Citigroup Inc C ‚ñº 52.83 -0.78 -1.46% Cash Converters International Ltd CCV ‚ñº 0.3600 -0.0050 -1.37% Certainly, both companies have far transcended their humble beginnings ‚Äì Target in suburban St. Paul, Minnesota, and Wal-Mart in Rogers, Arkansas. Yet today, they also stand at a challenging crossroads in a competitive digital age. This year, Target shares are off roughly 8 percent. But as recently as May, the stock was on a tear, up 12 percent from January through April. Then came May's second quarter earnings report, and investors punished Target after it aimed for the bull's-eye but instead hit the bear's behind. While earnings rose 16.5 percent, sales missed forecasts and guidance from the company was glum. Between May 10 and 18, Target stock plunged more than 16 percent; it currently trades close to $69 per share. [See: 7 of the Best Socially Responsible Funds.] Wal-Mart, on the other hand, has enjoyed a steady climb this year, so gradual and sublime you couldn't be blamed if you missed it. The stock, now trading at $72, is up more than 17 percent in 2016. Wal-Mart has few if any threats so far as copycats to its brick-and-mortar model, though its Sam's Club has a very close competitor in by Costco Wholesale Corp. (COST). Yet like Target, Wal-Mart faces stiff headwinds from other corners of the retail sphere. Thus, there's a strange apples-to-oranges parity between the two, and you don't have to hit the produce section to spot it. "While Target struggles to maintain a more than 6 percent lead over Wal-Mart in profit margin, Wal-Mart struggles to stay above the water from the inescapable e-commerce threat from Amazon.com (AMZN)," says K.C. Ma, director of the George Investments Institute at Stetson University in DeLand, Florida. Indeed, Amazon continues to dominate all things e-commerce, and passed Wal-Mart in July of last year as the world's largest retailer. But that's not to say Wal-Mart has given up on the digital front ‚Äì in fact, far from it. Wal-Mart hopes to grow its online sales around 20 to 30 percent in the near term by leveraging its tremendous distribution platform to support digital sales growth. Still, the explosion of e-commerce sets up a curious scenario where Wal-Mart and Target could face unlikely competitors: themselves. If nothing else, sales growth numbers may shed some light on where the companies stand. Figures provided by the investment analytics and financial research firm FactSet show sales growth hasn't been the best of stories for either Wal-Mart or Target. Since January 2013, Target has seen its growth decline from 4.9 percent to 1.6 percent in January of this year. Over the same period, Wal-Mart fell from 5.7 percent to -0.7 percent. Looking ahead, it's not much better: FactSet numbers project that by January 2017, Wal-Mart will inch up to 1 percent sales growth ‚Äì while Target will slide 5.6 percent. "By investing $2 billion in labor, health care and employee training for next two years, the benefit is immediate: Wal-Mart shareholders have been rewarded 5 percent for last six months," Ma says. Target, citing improvements "not recognized by the market," has seen its strategic shift met with returns of -4 percent. But at least on the social media front ‚Äì a metric that holds one key to retail success ‚Äì Target clearly holds the lead. NetBase's "Social Media Industry Report 2016: Retail Brands," examined the overall performance of 60 leading retail brands across social channels. On the one hand, the social analytics company found Target and Wal-Mart close in terms of social outreach. "Target was second in mentions and Wal-Mart fourth," says Paige Leidig, CMO at NetBase. "Target's reach, mentions and awareness ranks were all comparable. But Target's brand passion index ranking was 41st while Wal-Mart's was 51st, suggesting that Target conversation was both more positive and more passionate." No. 1 on the mentions rank? Amazon. Tiffany and Co. (TIF) scored tops in the brand passion category. But if there were such thing as the broker passion index, the luxury jeweler would hold all the appeal of cubic zirconia: TIF stock is off almost 4 percent for the year. Meanwhile, the rise of dollar stores proves that some outlets can out-bargain a Wal-Mart or Target bargain. Wall Street types are definitely noticing: Dollar General Corp. (DG) in particular was high octane, up 26 percent this year until August. A disappointing earnings report tripped up DG stock, but nine out of 20 analysts still rate it a "strong buy." What's more, TGT and WMT stand apart from their retail peers for dubious reasons. Both have been dogged in recent years by bad publicity and a costly aftermath. Target's big data breach of 2013 whacked 40 million customers, and almost singlehandedly accelerated the adoption of EMV chip-based credit cards in the U.S. (Yes, Target takes them.) All told, the breach cost Target $252 million. Yet that's chump change compared to the setbacks Wal-Mart weathered after getting drubbed for its draconian labor practices. In response, the company enacted reforms that began last year and will increase wages by a total of $2.7 billion. And while that has made the worker bees happier, market watchers consider it quite the buzzkill. After the breach, Target made a smart move to right the ship. New CEO Brian Cornell, who came on board in August 2014, closed Target's underperforming Canadian operation and focused on transparency with the U.S. customer base. Cornell has also heralded a shift to a more focused consumer strategy and it's working, Ma says: "While Wal-Mart has been struggled to find the sweet spot to match the right prices and quality of products to carry, Target has returned to smaller, healthier, high-end stores with higher profit margins. So which mega retailer holds the advantage in the end? In the spirit of the political season, Ma makes his forecast: "Forward-looking valuation models suggest that WMT has a fair value around $80, approximately 9 percent undervalued. TGT has a fair value of $74 with 7 percent undervaluation," he says. "So if the election happened today, Wal-Mart would win." Contact Us KOIN 6 on Instagram Survivor Casting Call About KOIN 6 News KOIN 6 News Team Contests KOIN 6 Mobile KOIN 6 Text Alerts KOIN 6 News Email Alerts Job Postings KOIN Media KOIN 6 Internships Search for: Search the site 56¬∞ F Overcast Hi: 56¬∞ F Lo: 52¬∞ F Accused Hazel Dell Walmart shooter charged Shaun Sprague was armed with a revolver By Brent Weisberg and KOIN 6 News staff Published: October 7, 2016, 6:12 am Updated: October 7, 2016, 6:51 am Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window) Click to share on Google+ (Opens in new window) Share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Click to share on Pinterest (Opens in new window) Police take pictures of a gun used in a shooting inside a Hazel Dell Walmart, October 5, 2016 (KOIN/Douglas Key) VANCOUVER, Wash. (KOIN) ‚Äì The man accused of opening fire inside a Subway restaurant inside a Hazel Dell Walmart is facing charges. Shaun Sprague appeared in Clark County court on Thursday where he was charged with three counts of first-degree assault and one count of first-degree arson. On Wednesday, Clark County deputies say that Sprague walked into the Walmart along Highway 99 around 6:11 a.m., armed with a revolver. At 6:54 a.m., he was contacted by the Subway manager. The manager walked away and when behind the counter, according to court documents. ‚ÄúAt that time, Sprague points the revolver [at the manager],‚Äù court documents state. Sprague lowered the gun, but then pointed it at the manager a second time. At that point, the manager fled. As the manager ran away, Sprague turned to a group of pumpkins that had been set up inside the store and fired ‚Äúmultiple rounds inside the store.‚Äù The shooting was all captured on video. Detectives learned that Sprague wanted to buy a sandwich but was told the restaurant didn‚Äôt open until 7 a.m. The manager told investigators that he recalled hearing 6 initial shot followed by 2 more shots. When law enforcement arrived, Sprague was taken into custody without incident. No one was hurt. He told detectives that he had owned the gun for about 5 years, according to court documents. ‚ÄúSprague advised [detectives] he had been cold and wet when he went inside of the Walmart,‚Äù according to court documents. ‚ÄúHe advised that he had planned on killing himself while there but changed his mind.‚Äù While Sprague was sitting inside a jail holding cell, he told an investigator that he had used ‚Äúspeed‚Äù a couple days ago. He said, ‚Äúnone of this would have happened before I used that [redacted.]‚Äù The arson charge that Sprague faces stems from a separate incident that occurred Tuesday night in the 3000 block of Northeast 75th. Investigators say that Sprague started a kitchen fire and then found the gas line to the home‚Äôs water heater disconnected. Records show that Sprague lived at the residence and his roommate was home and had to put the fire out with water. Sprague is due back in court later this month. Early indications are that the president-elect‚Ä¶ Accounting & Tax Banking & Capital Markets Risk & Compliance Human Capital & Careers Growth Companies Strategy Technology M&A Wal-Mart Doubles Stake in China‚Äôs JD.com Four months after acquiring 5.9% of JD.com, Wal-Mart has become the third largest shareholder in the Chinese e-commerce company. Matthew Heller October 7, 2016 | CFO.com | US share Tweet Email Print - Print + Email this article To* Please enter your email address* Subject* Comments* Wal-Mart has almost doubled its stake in JD.com, becoming the third-largest shareholder in China‚Äôs second-largest e-commerce company. In a regulatory filing, Wal-Mart disclosed it now owns 265 million shares in JD.com, or 10.8% of shares that don‚Äôt have extra voting power, up from the 5.9% stake it obtained by selling Yihaodian, its Chinese online marketplace, to JD in June. Recommended Stories: Adobe Buys Ad Tech Firm TubeMogul for $540M Windstream to Buy Dial-Up Pioneer Earthlink Wanda Group Buys Dick Clark Productions for $1B The increased stake is just short of the level that would allow Wal-Mart to gain observer status at JD.com‚Äôs board meetings. JD‚Äôs two largest shareholders are Tencent, China‚Äôs dominant social networking company, which has a stake of 21.25%, and founder Liu Qiangdong, who owns 16.2%. ‚ÄúThe stepped-up investment in JD has been part of our plan, as we continue to be a passive investor,‚Äù a a Wal-Mart spokeswoman said. ‚ÄúWe believe this strategic alliance will help us grow e-commerce even faster in China.‚Äù As The Wall Street Journal reports, the sale of Yihaodian reflected Wal-Mart‚Äôs shift in strategy to ‚Äúseeking to navigate China‚Äôs competitive e-commerce market as an investor in a major local player, rather than trying to expand its own online shopping platform.‚Äù ‚ÄúChina has surpassed the U.S. as the world‚Äôs largest e-commerce market. But it is a challenging market for foreign players, as the country‚Äôs fast-growing online shopping sector is dominated by domestic competitors like JD.com and Alibaba Group Holding Ltd., China‚Äôs largest e-commerce company,‚Äù the WSJ explained. At JD‚Äôs closing price of $27.40 on Thursday, Wal-Mart‚Äôs stake was worth more than $7.2 billion. Last month, the retailer was reportedly in advanced talks with India e-commerce company Flipkart for an investment of about $1 billion. Menu Stocks Stocks to Buy Stocks to Sell Dividend Stocks Penny Stocks Hot Stocks Stock Market Today Funds Mutual Funds ETF Investing 401k & Investing Tips Retirement Financial Advisor Center Trading Trading Advice Trade of the Day Trading Report How to Trade Options Market Insight IPO Playbook Gadgets, Smartphones & Tech Weird Street InvestorPolitics Financial Advisors Premium Services IPO Playbook Gadgets, Smartphones & Tech Weird Street InvestorPolitics Hot Topics AAPL FB Best Stocks for 2016 Trade of the Day Dependable Dividends Best ETFs More Home > Market Insight, Financial Articles > The Calm Before the Earnings Season Storm Here's a quick look ahead to the earnings start By Louis Navellier, Editor, Blue Chip Growth¬†¬†|¬†¬†Oct 7, 2016, 6:30 am EST ¬† ¬† Popular Posts: 7 Blue-Chip Stocks That Are Due for a Reckoning 7 A-Rated Cheap Stocks to Buy for Rapid-Fire Growth 7 Fantastic Stocks That No One Talks About Recent Posts: 7 Blue-Chip Stocks That Are Due for a Reckoning Transdigm Group Incorporated (TDG) Stock: The Sky‚Äôs the Limit Avoid These 7 Big-Name Biotechs and Pharmaceuticals View All Posts Thursday, the major indices opened down as investors collectively held their breath for third-quarter earnings season to start tonight. And I must admit that I can‚Äôt blame them. Analysts expect the S&P 500 as a whole to see profits contract 2.1% compared with last year. So now more than ever, it‚Äôs crucial to keep track of earnings. But considering that upwards of 50 companies will report operating results each and every trading day over the next several weeks, I don‚Äôt expect you to spend hours of your day combing through the data. Instead, I‚Äôll do that for you and hit the highlights in this daily blog. However, before I do, let me say that Walmart Stores, Inc. (WMT) made headlines Thursday with its lackluster earnings outlook for the next two fiscal years. WMT shares fell after the company announced that it would open fewer stores, and focus more on its online business. Walmart will release its Q3 results in mid-November, and it will be interesting to see how this report shakes out. In the meantime, I consider WMT a B-rated (cautious) buy. Today, I‚Äôll preview the biggest names to keep on your radar over the next several trading days: There are only five names scheduled to report¬†today,¬†including Oil-Dri Corporation of America¬†(ODC), Straight Path Communications Inc¬†(STRP) and TSR Inc¬†(TSRI). Respectively, these stocks are rated A, C and B in Portfolio Grader. Monday: This Monday will also be a relatively quiet day for earnings. You can click here to see the full lineup. The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for the Rest of 2016 Tuesday: Before Tuesday‚Äôs open, Alcoa Inc¬†(AA) kicks off the official start to earnings season by announcing its third-quarter operating results. Now, Alcoa‚Äôs earnings are expected to improve from 7 cents per share a year ago to 13 cents per share. However, if you currently hold shares of the world‚Äôs leading aluminum producer, you may want to brace yourself: AA fails in Portfolio Grader (it currently is a D-rated Sell). This is due to a combination of anemic buying pressure and mixed fundamentals. For the rest of next week, we‚Äôll have several more high-profile earnings reports. On Wednesday, October 12, CSX Corporaton¬†(CSX) and Delta Air Lines, Inc.¬†(DAL) will release their quarterly results. On Thursday, we‚Äôll hear from Progressive Corp¬†(PGR) and Wynn Resorts, Ltd¬†(WYNN). Friday will be a big day for the banking industry, with Citigroup Inc¬†(C), JPMorgan Chase & Co.¬†(JPM), PNC Financial Services Group Inc¬†(PNC) and Wells Fargo & Co¬†(WFC) all reporting before the market opens. As a whole, this earnings season is going to be very challenging, especially for energy and financial stocks. There are exceptions to the rule. In Wednesday‚Äôs blog, I featured Constellation Brands, Inc.‚Äôs¬†(STZ) Q2 earnings report. The stock is still rising after its 7% earnings surprise and its 3% sales surprise. 5 Stocks to Sell Now or Short Into the Ground I currently recommend STZ in Blue Chip Growth and it is a B-rated Buy in Portfolio Grader. Make no mistake‚Äîthe next several weeks will shake up the market as earnings take center stage. So be sure to check in on this blog from time to time to help you locate the best profit opportunities in this shifting market. DFS sitting pretty as sales approach ¬£1 billion: DFS promised shareholders a special dividend next year after profits nearly doubled and sales neared ¬£1 billion. Carry on with QE, Draghi is told: Mario Draghi has been given the backing of the governing council of the European Central Bank to extend the ‚Ç¨80 billion-a-month quantitative easing programme beyond March if inflation remains sluggish. Gloom at Dunelm as shoppers bask in late summer sunshine: Dunelm Group has blamed warm weather for a slump in first-quarter sales that sent revenues below ¬£200 million. Wal-Mart sees flat future as it cuts new shops to boost online: Wal-Mart Stores, the American Owner of Asda, has cut its profit forecast for the next two years after deciding to push deeper into online sales. Banking complaints fall with PPI claims: The number of people complaining to the Financial Conduct Authority about their bank fell over the first half of the year to just over two million, driven largely by a drop in payment protection insurance mis-selling claims and fewer rows about current-account services. Bank‚Äôs ¬£507 million bond buying beats forecasts: The Bank of England has bought ¬£507 million of corporate bonds since it began the latest part of its quantitative easing programme last week, far in excess of analysts‚Äô forecasts. The Independent Pound hits another 31-year low as Chancellor Philip Hammond launches Wall Street charm offensive: A wave of selling has swept the pound down to a fresh 31-year low against the dollar on Wednesday, as Chancellor Philip Hammond flies to New York to reassure U.S. banks after the U.K. voted to leave the EU. Brexit could cost Scotland 80,000 jobs and ¬£2,000 per person: Scotland could lose 80,000 jobs and up to ¬£2,000 per person in GDP if the U.K. pursues a ‚Äòhard Brexit‚Äô, according to new analysis. Philip Hammond: Government will not pursue ‚Äòhard Brexit‚Äô: Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond dismissed mounting speculation that the British government is turning anti-business as it prepares to leave the European Union. Sunderland ‚Äòworried‚Äô about Nissan‚Äôs threat to put investment on hold: Paul Watson, the leader of Sunderland council, said people are worried about Nissan‚Äôs threat to scrap a potential new investment in the city‚Äôs car plant, which provides work for 7,000 people. BAE in arms talks with Saudi Arabia despite kingdom‚Äôs alleged war crimes in Yemen: BAE Systems has disclosed it is in talks to secure a multi-billion pound arms contract with Saudi Arabia, despite alleged war crimes by the Middle Eastern kingdom using British-made weapons in war-torn Yemen. The Daily Telegraph Fracking go-ahead: Government approves Cuadrilla plans, overruling Lancashire council: Fracking beneath U.K. homes is set to take place for the first time next year after the Government overruled local councillors and approved Cuadrilla‚Äôs plans to explore for shale gas in Lancashire. EasyJet braces for ¬£90 million profit hit from currency plunge: EasyJet is bracing for a ¬£90 million profit hit this year after the plunge in sterling dealt a heavier than expected blow to the no-frills carrier as it is forced to slash ticket prices to battle a drop in demand for holidays abroad. Snapchat working on $25 billion IPO: Snapchat‚Äôs parent company is working on a stock market listing that could value the virtual messaging company at up to $25 billion (¬£19.8 billion). Saudi Aramco IPO to offer shares in whole company: Saudi Aramco, the world‚Äôs biggest oil company, is planning to sell shares in its entire business and give investors unprecedented access to its financials ahead of its $2 trillion stock exchange listing. Bank cheerleader Angela Knight joins Arbuthnot board: Angela Knight, the former Head of the British Bankers‚Äô Association, has joined the board of merchant bank Arbuthnot. Suez buys stake in specialist recycling firm TerraCycle: French waste management company Suez is buying 30% of specialist recycling business TerraCycle in a deal that will enable it to recycle items such as coffee pods, cigarette butts and biscuit wrappers for the first time. The Guardian Mark Carney backs prime minister‚Äôs call for economic shake-up: Mark Carney has backed the Prime Minister‚Äôs call to rethink Britain‚Äôs economic policy and rejected the idea that criticism of the side-effects of unconventional measures amounted to an attack on the independence of the Bank of England. IMF and World Bank launch defence of open markets and free trade: The leaders of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank have launched a strong defence of open markets and free trade, as concern grows that the Brexit vote and calls for protectionism in the U.S. presidential election represent a backlash against globalisation. Civil service women see gender pay gap grow: Female civil servants‚Äô earnings have fallen further behind those of their male colleagues, following a widening of the sector‚Äôs gender pay gap that has bucked broader trends in the U.K. Immigration crackdown could lead to staff shortages, say recruiters: Fresh evidence of skills shortages has fanned fears about British companies‚Äô long-term prospects if the government follows through on talk of an immigration crackdown. Government could buy developers‚Äô unsold homes under ¬£2 billion fund: A ¬£2 billion fund to boost housebuilding could be used by the government to offer guarantees to developers that it will step in to take on properties that they are unable to sell. Hamleys unveils Christmas toys it hopes will fly off the shelves: It may still be October but the toy store Hamleys is already predicting that a Star Wars drone and a caterpillar designed to help toddlers develop their critical thinking will be among its bestsellers this Christmas. U.K. productivity back at pre-crash level, but lagging behind G7: The U.K.‚Äôs productivity rate has returned to its pre-crisis level for the first time, but the country still lags well behind other major economies after years of sluggish growth. Daily Mail Troubled Deutsche Bank axes another 1,000 German jobs on top of the 3,000 losses announced in June: Deutsche Bank is slashing another 1,000 jobs in Germany as the beleaguered lender battles to convince investors it has a solid future. The reduction is on top of 3,000 German job losses announced in June. An ¬£8.1 million payday for Boss of private equity firm SVG Capital in takeover war: The Chief Executive of private equity firm SVG Capital is set to pocket up to ¬£8.1 million following a fierce bidding war to take over the business. Goldman Sachs and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board have launched a ¬£1.1 billion joint bid to buy SVG. Sterling hits fresh 31-year low against the dollar as investors fret over the prospect of a ‚Äòhard Brexit‚Äô: Sterling has hit a fresh 31-year low against the U.S. dollar as investors fretted over the prospect of a ‚Äòhard Brexit‚Äô following Britain‚Äôs vote to leave the European Union. The pound fell to as low as $1.2623 at one stage and ‚Ç¨1.13 against the single currency on another brutal day. Sales leap for OKA Direct, the furniture retailer run by Samantha Cameron‚Äôs mother: OKA Direct, the furniture retailer run by Samantha Cameron‚Äôs mother Lady Astor , is to expand after a sales boost from its home accessories range. IGas up by 15% after government gives the green light to Cuadrilla to begin fracking in Lancashire: Energy firms caught traders‚Äô attention as the Government threw its weight behind the British shale revolution. Daily Express Boost to London stock Exchange as Misys press button on ¬£5 billion float: Banking software firm Misys endorsed London‚Äôs financial services credentials as it pressed the button on a potential ¬£5.5 billion stock market return, making it the U.K.‚Äôs biggest float this year. Merkel tells U.K. to accept free movement of EU migrants if it wants part of single market: German Chancellor Angela Merkel insisted the U.K. will have to accept free movement of EU migrants if it wants to be part of the free-trade single market. The Scottish Herald Scots law firm posts solid set of results: Edinburgh-headquartered law firm Morton Fraser has hailed the 2015/16 financial year as the one in which it consolidated its cash-positive position. Spending cuts impact Dundee tooth maker: Wright Heath Group, the Dundee-based dental supplies business chaired by Sir Angus Grossart, has increased profits by 46% in its latest year in spite of the challenges posed by cuts in government and consumer spending. Edinburgh firm turns to India for inspiration for its latest international whisky fusion: It is one of the fastest growing global markets for Scotch whisky, importing 41 million bottles in the first half of the year. Now India is on the agenda as the next international port of call for a company whose fusions of Scotch and Japanese whiskies sold out within weeks of their launch. Clyde Union hit by the oil and gas slide: Clyde Union has cited the global downturn in oil and gas industry investment as it slumped to a ¬£1.5 million loss and cut its workforce further last year. Rising yen aids Baillie Gifford Japan trust: An appreciating yen and depreciating pound coupled with the strong performance of several internet-related holdings helped the Baillie Gifford Japan Trust post a strong set of results for the last financial year. The Scotsman Scottish gold to hit shelves in time for Christmas: The company behind Scotland‚Äôs first commercial gold mine is on track to start selling its precious metal before the end of this year. Burrito business launches third Edinburgh site: A Mexican-style burrito chain has opened its third outlet in Edinburgh, in a city centre site formerly occupied by Starbucks. Edinburgh‚Äôs largest office set for overhaul: Record-low vacancy levels have triggered a contemporary take on refurbishment in Edinburgh‚Äôs single largest office building, which is being overhauled with an eye to the capital‚Äôs booming tech sector. City A.M. Megabrew merger between AB InBev and SABMiller inches closer as SAB shares suspend trading on London Stock Exchange: Shares in British drinks giant SABMiller suspended trading on the London Stock Exchange this morning as the Megabrew merger between SAB and Belgian beer giant Anheuser-Busch InBev inches closer. Peer-to-peer mortgage lender LendInvest posts a 133% rise in revenue as profit flattens out: Peer-to-peer (P2P) mortgage company LendInvest has posted a 133% increase in gross revenues for the year to 31 March 2016. Mobile is the invisible infrastructure that can drive the economy in post-Brexit Britain: This week‚Äôs State of Mobile Networks report served as a timely reminder of the importance that people and businesses across the U.K. place on mobile connectivity, particularly superfast 4G. Amazon‚Äôs unstoppable expansion continues with new warehouse in Northamptonshire: Amazon has announced plans to open a new warehouse in Daventry, Northamptonshire, in 2017, creating 300 new jobs. –¢–µ—Ä–º–∏–Ω–∞–ª –§–æ–Ω–¥–æ–≤—ã–π —Ä—ã–Ω–æ–∫ –£–ö–† –†–£–° ENG –ü—Ä–µ—Å—Å-—Ü–µ–Ω—Ç—Ä –ü—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç—ã –∏ —É—Å–ª—É–≥–∏ –û–± –∞–≥–µ–Ω—Ç—Å—Ç–≤–µ –ì–ª–∞–≤–Ω–∞—è –°–æ–±—ã—Ç–∏—è –ü–æ–ª–∏—Ç–∏–∫–∞ –≠–∫–æ–Ω–æ–º–∏–∫–∞ –ù–µ—Ñ—Ç—å –í–∏–¥–µ–æ –°–ø–æ—Ä—Ç –ú–µ–¥–∏—Ü–∏–Ω–∞ –í–∞–∫–∞–Ω—Å–∏–∏ –¢–µ—Å—Ç–æ–≤—ã–π –¥–æ—Å—Ç—É–ø –°–ü–ï–¶–¢–ï–ú–´: –ë—é–¥–∂–µ—Ç –°–Ω–µ–≥–æ–ø–∞–¥ –ì–∞–∑ –ö—Ä—ã–º –ö—É—Ä—Å –≥—Ä–∏–≤–Ω–∏ –ï-–¥–µ–∫–ª–∞—Ä–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –ê–¢–û –†–ï–ö–õ–ê–ú–ê –†–ï–ö–õ–ê–ú–ê –†–ï–ö–õ–ê–ú–ê –†–ï–ö–õ–ê–ú–ê Loading... –†–ï–ö–õ–ê–ú–ê –†–ï–ö–õ–ê–ú–ê –†–ï–ö–õ–ê–ú–ê –†–ï–ö–õ–ê–ú–ê http://tvgid.ua –†–ï–ö–õ–ê–ú–ê –ü–û–ì–û–î–ê –∏–∑—É—á–µ–Ω–∏–µ –∞–Ω–≥–ª–∏–π—Å–∫–æ–≥–æ –≤–∞–∫–∞–Ω—Å–∏–∏ –≤ —á–µ—Ä–∫–∞—Å—Å–∞—Ö –ö–≤–∞—Ä—Ç–∏—Ä—ã –≤ –í–∏—à–Ω–µ–≤–æ–º –†–ï–ö–õ–ê–ú–ê –ü—Ä–µ—Å—Å-—Ü–µ–Ω—Ç—Ä –ü—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç—ã –∏ —É—Å–ª—É–≥–∏ –ú–æ–±–∏–ª—å–Ω–∞—è –≤–µ—Ä—Å–∏—è –í–∞–∫–∞–Ω—Å–∏–∏ –û–± –∞–≥–µ–Ω—Ç—Å—Ç–≤–µ ¬© 1992-2016, –ò–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–∞–∫—Å-–£–∫—Ä–∞–∏–Ω–∞. –í—Å–µ –ø—Ä–∞–≤–∞ –∑–∞—â–∏—â–µ–Ω—ã –í—Å—è –∏–Ω—Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∞—Ü–∏—è, —Ä–∞–∑–º–µ—â–µ–Ω–Ω–∞—è –Ω–∞ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–º –≤–µ–±-—Å–∞–π—Ç–µ, –ø—Ä–µ–¥–Ω–∞–∑–Ω–∞—á–µ–Ω–∞ —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –¥–ª—è –ø–µ—Ä—Å–æ–Ω–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ–≥–æ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è –∏ –Ω–µ –ø–æ–¥–ª–µ–∂–∏—Ç –¥–∞–ª—å–Ω–µ–π—à–µ–º—É –≤–æ—Å–ø—Ä–æ–∏–∑–≤–µ–¥–µ–Ω–∏—é –∏/–∏–ª–∏ —Ä–∞—Å–ø—Ä–æ—Å—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω–µ–Ω–∏—é –≤ –∫–∞–∫–æ–π-–ª–∏–±–æ —Ñ–æ—Ä–º–µ, –∏–Ω–∞—á–µ –∫–∞–∫ —Å –ø–∏—Å—å–º–µ–Ω–Ω–æ–≥–æ —Ä–∞–∑—Ä–µ—à–µ–Ω–∏—è "–ò–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–∞–∫—Å-–£–∫—Ä–∞–∏–Ω–∞". –£–∫—Ä–∞–∏–Ω–∞ –°–®–ê –ë—Ä–∏—Ç–∞–Ω–∏—è –†–æ—Å—Å–∏—è –ö–∞–∑–∞—Ö—Å—Ç–∞–Ω –ë–µ–ª–∞—Ä—É—Å—å
Toggle Navigation A- ¬†¬†A+ Sign in News ¬† Stock Home ¬´Back Mixed and flat finish for US stocks Capital Market¬†|¬† Oct 07, 2016 11:21 AM IST Wal-Mart Stores and American Express weighed on the blue-chip benchmark U.S. stocks finished on flat and mixed note on Thursday, 06 October 2016. Investors abstained from making big bets ahead of Friday's much-anticipated September jobs report. Stocks sold off in early trade, but the market recouped much of its losses after a high-ranking European Central Bank official repudiated reports that the central bank had discussed tapering its bond-buying program.Aside from central bank policies and economic data, earnings are looming as an important market driver. The Dow Jones Industrial Average shed 12.53 points to finish at 18,268.50. The Nasdaq Composite Index declined 9.17 points, or 0.2%, to close at 5,306.85, pressured by losses in biotechs. The S&P 500 index edged up 1.04 points to close at 2,160.77, with the materials sector topping the gains. Sharp losses in Wal-Mart Stores and American Express weighed on the blue-chip benchmark. Wal-Mart Stores shares fell 3.2% after the retailer provided a lackluster outlook for 2017 at an investor meeting. Wal-Mart is a component of both the S&P 500 and the Dow industrials. Trading was generally tepid as investors awaited Friday's jobs data, which will help them gauge the likelihood that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates before the end of 2016. Ahead of the jobs report, Thursday's weekly jobless claims report pointed to extremely low levels of layoffs, suggesting that employers are reluctant to part with workers in a tight market. Meanwhile, ECB Vice President Victor Constancio reportedly said there is no consensus to wind down bond purchases. There were earlier reports this week that bank officials had reached an informal consensus to taper the ECB's quantitative-easing efforts sooner than expected. The denial from the ECB is in keeping with market expectations that the ECB is reluctant to exit its quantitative-easing program and that it is more inclined to extend its loose monetary policy stance beyond March. Mr. Constancio briefly rallied global bond markets when he denied reports from earlier in the week that suggested the central bank has held discussions about tapering its asset purchase program. That headline boost proved to be short-lived, however, as Treasury prices soon started to fade again, pushing yields back up. Today's economic data was limited to Challenger Job Cuts for September and weekly initial claims. September Challenger Job Cuts reported in at 44,300, which compares to the prior month's reading of 32,200. For the week ending 1 October, initial claims decreased by 5,000 to 249,000 (consensus 258,000). Continuing claims for the week ending September 24 fell by 6,000 to 2.058 million. Economic data showed that the number of people who applied for unemployment benefits fell by 5,000 to 249,000 in the final week of September, which bodes well for a strong payrolls number. The yield on the benchmark 10-yr note, which slipped back to 1.71% after the Constancio headline first hit, finished higher by four basis points at 1.74%. Third-quarter earnings season will kick off unofficially on Tuesday with Alcoa's results. Oil futures continued to climb, trading above $50 a barrel for the first time in four months. Gold futures retreated as a key dollar index gained. European stocks fell while Asian markets closed higher. Today's participation was below the recent average as more than 796 million shares changed hands at the NYSE floor. Tomorrow's economic data will include the 8:30 a.m. ET release of the Employment Situation Report for September. The consensus expects the report to show an increase of 176,000 in nonfarm payrolls. Meanwhile, August Wholesale Inventories (consensus -0.1%) and August Consumer Credit (consensus$18.0 billion) will cross the wires at 10:00 a.m ET and 3:00 p.m. ET, respectively. Skip to main content Top Menu Mobile Apps ePaper Login Subscribe Now Kingston Mon | Nov 14, 2016 Search Menu Main menu Home Lead Stories News Sports Entertainment Business Letters Commentary Flair Health Food Secondary Menu World News Lifestyle In Focus Auto Social Outlook Shipping Western Focus Art & Leisure Jobs Power 106 Classifieds Mobile version Subscribe to this feed Join us on Facebook Follow us on Twitter Wal-Mart plans to slow store openings, invest more online Published:Friday | October 7, 2016 | 12:00 AM Photo Video AP In this September 19, 2013 file photo, customers walk outside of a Wal-mart store in San Jose, California. Wal-Mart Stores Inc plans to slow its new store openings and pour more money into its online efforts, technology and store remodels, the company said on Thursday. The world's largest retailer also tempered its outlook, saying it anticipates fiscal 2018 earnings per share being about flat with its fiscal 2017 adjusted earnings per share. It foresees fiscal 2019 earnings-per-share growth of about five per cent. Wal-Mart completed its more than US$3-billion buyout of the fast-growing online retailer, Jet.com, last month, showing how heavily it's willing to invest to boost online sales that totalled US$13.7 billion last year - still just a fraction of its annual revenue. "This company is going to look more like an e-commerce company," CEO Doug McMillon told analysts at the company's annual investment meeting. Like its direct store rivals, Wal-Mart is trying to be more nimble as it fights off competition from online leader Amazon.com, whose Prime shopping programme is swiftly converting members into loyal shoppers. And it faces competition from dollar stores and traditional grocers like Kroger, which are ramping up promotions. But Wal-Mart has seen its investments online and in the stores pay off - and it's starting to gain ground over some of the competitors. It has launched a flurry of changes, from making sure its vegetables look good to cleaning up its stores to being sharper on keeping prices low. The company has 150 fresh-food managers working to train store sales associates. Online grocery shopping Wal-Mart is also melding online services with its massive fleet of stores. It rolled out a mobile payment system to speed checkouts. And it's pushing ahead with online grocery and pickup services. Greg Foran, CEO and president of Wal-Mart's US namesake business, told analysts on Thursday that by the end of the year, it will have grocery online pickup services at 600 US stores. The company is in the second year of its US$2.7-billion investment in its workers that involves higher pay and more training. It says that such investments as well as the other moves are already helping to improve customer service in the stores. Wal-Mart had raised its annual profit outlook in August after reporting its eighth straight quarterly increase in revenue of stores opened at least a year and the seventh quarterly gain in customer traffic at its namesake Wal-Mart US business. Global online sales rose 11.8 per cent in the second quarter. That's up from the seven per cent pace of the first quarter but still far weaker than the 20 per cent increases from less than two years ago. McMillon reiterated to analysts on Thursday that he believes the Jet.com acquisition will help it attract higher-income and younger customers. The company plans to incorporate some of Jet.com's technology that lowers prices in real time. As part of the deal, Marc Lore, co-founder and CEO of Jet.com, is overseeing both the site and Walmart.com. "I look around and see the vast assets," Lore told investors on Thursday. "This is the perfect time to accelerate the business." Foran said that Lore will be working to increasingly get the store and online selections to match, so if customers see something in the store, they'll know they can find it online. Increasing stake in JD.com The retailer still has plenty of challenges, notably in China, and it's struggling in the United Kingdom and Brazil. It announced on Wednesday that it was increasing its stake in JD.com, China's No. 2 e-commerce site, to 10.8 per cent from 5.9 per cent. That comes nearly four months after Wal-Mart bought an initial stake in JD.com in a deal that also gave JD.com ownership of the Chinese e-commerce site Yihaodian, including the brand and app. Wal-Mart said on Thursday it would spend US$11 billion on capital expenditures this year, and the same for the following fiscal year. In the fiscal year ended in January, the company spent US$11.5 billion on capital expenditures. But Wal-Mart said it will be investing more of that money in e-commerce and digital initiatives. The company also said that it plans to open 130 US stores this year, but that's below its forecast issued last year that it would open 135 to 155 new stores. In its last fiscal year, it opened 230 US stores. It said it plans to open another 55 US stores next year. Wal-Mart reiterated that its earnings per share for the current year on an adjusted basis would be US$4.15 per share to US$4.35 per share on an adjusted basis. - AP ¬´[node:title] Haiti to get US$20m insurance payout¬ª View the discussion thread. ¬† ¬† Search ¬†Horoscope India Politics Crime All India World South Asia Asia Middle East Africa Europe Americas Oceania Metros Delhi Kolkata Mumbai In Other Cities Business Economy Market Companies Autos In Other News Opinion Edit Oped Columnists Interview of the Week Reporter's Diary The Age Debate Here and Now Sports Cricket Tennis Football In Other sports Technology Mobiles & Tabs Gadgets In Other news Reviews Entertainment Bollywood Hollywood Movie Reviews TV Music In Other News Photos Life Health Fashion Food Travel Art Relationship More Features Newsmakers Books Science Horoscope Delhi Age Mumbai Age Age on Sunday Editors' Picks ¬†¬† e-Paper | Age on Sunday ¬†Auto Refresh ¬†Search ¬† Horoscope Monday, Nov 14, 2016 | Last Update : 12:38 PM IST Home India World Metros Business Opinion Sports Technology Entertainment Photos Life Newsmakers More ¬† Books Science Horoscope Delhi Age Mumbai Age Age on Sunday Editors' Picks Business Walmart plans to slow new store openings, invest in online AP Published : Oct 7, 2016, 10:40 am IST Updated : Oct 7, 2016, 10:40 am IST The world's largest retailer completed its more than $3 billion buyout of the fast-growing online retailer Jet.com last month. ¬†walmart_0_0_1_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0.jpg The world's largest retailer completed its more than $3 billion buyout of the fast-growing online retailer Jet.com last month. New York: WalMart Stores Inc. plans to slow its new store openings and pour more money into its online efforts, technology and store remodels, the company said Thursday. The world's largest retailer completed its more than $3 billion buyout of the fast-growing online retailer Jet.com last month, showing how heavily it's willing to invest to boost online sales that totaled $13.7 billion last year - still just a fraction of its annual revenue. "This company is going to look more like an e-commerce company," CEO Doug McMillon told analysts at the company's annual investment meeting. WalMart also tempered its outlook, saying it anticipates fiscal 2018 earnings per share being about flat with its fiscal 2017 adjusted earnings per share. It foresees fiscal 2019 earnings per share growth of about 5 percent. The company's shares fell $2.12, or 3 percent, to $69.55 in afternoon trading. Still, the outlook wasn't as bad as a year ago, when executives said earnings per share could fall 6 percent to 12 percent this year because of investments in higher salaries and e-commerce. That day, Walmart shares plunged 10 percent. But WalMart's flurry of moves - online and in the stores - have been gaining traction, and its shares were up 17 percent this year ahead of the meeting. Like its direct store rivals, WalMart is trying to be more nimble as it fights off competition from online leader Amazon.com. And it faces competition from dollar stores and traditional grocers like Kroger, which are ramping up promotions. Walmart launched a number of changes, from making sure its vegetables look good to cleaning up its stores to being sharper on keeping prices low. The company has 150 fresh food managers working to train sales associates. The company is also melding online services with its massive fleet of stores. It rolled out a mobile payment system to speed checkouts. And it's pushing ahead with online grocery and pick-up services. Greg Foran, CEO and president of Walmart's U.S. namesake business, told analysts Thursday that by the end of the year, it will have grocery online pickup services at 600 U.S. stores. Walmart had raised its annual profit outlook in August after reporting its eighth straight quarterly increase in revenue of stores opened at least a year. In contrast, rival Target reported that a key revenue measure was down 1.1 percent in the second quarter, after seven straight quarters of gains. And it saw fewer customers in the store for the first time in a year and a half. Walmart's online sales rose 11.8 percent in the second quarter - up from 7 percent in the first quarter but still trailing the 20 percent increases from less than two years ago. Officials said Thursday they believe its global online sales will be up 20 percent to 30 percent in the second half of this year. Walmart also reiterated that its earnings per share for the current year on an adjusted basis would be $4.15 per share to $4.35 per share on an adjusted basis. McMillon stressed to analysts Thursday that he believes the Jet.com acquisition will help the company attract higher-income and younger customers. Walmart plans to incorporate some of Jet.com's technology that lowers prices in real time. As part of the deal, Marc Lore, co-founder and CEO of Jet.com, is overseeing both the site and Walmart.com. "I look around and see the vast assets," Lore told investors Thursday. "This is the perfect time to accelerate the business." Foran said that Lore will be working to increasingly get the store and online selections to match, so if customers see something in the store, they'll know they can find it online. The retailer still has plenty of challenges. Analysts questioned whether the price cuts that Walmart is taking will be sustainable as rivals respond. And they asked executives how much profit they would be willing to risk. Walmart had said it is spending several billion dollars in its plans to lower prices, but haven't given any specific details. McMillon declined to talk about how much farther they would be willing to go. Walmart did say Thursday it would spend $11 billion on capital expenditures this year, and the same for the following fiscal year. In the fiscal year ended in January, the company spent $11.5 billion on capital expenditures. But Walmart said it will be investing more of that money in e-commerce and digital initiatives. The company also said it plans to open 130 U.S. stores this year, but that's below its forecast issued last year that it would open 135 to 155 new stores. In its last fiscal year, it opened 230 U.S. stores. It said it plans to open another 55 U.S. stores next year. By type of store, Walmart plans to open 60 supercenters and 70 of the smaller-format Neighborhood Markets this year. For next year, the breakdown is 35 supercenters and 20 smaller-format stores. Photo by Robert Cohen, rcohen@post-dispatch.com Handout Two Walmart smaller-format Neighborhood Market stores opened in St. Peters in early 2016.¬† Close NOTES * Dollar Tree acquired Family Dollar in July 2015, boosting its local store count. ** Report defines St. Louis region as St. Louis and the Missouri counties of Jefferson, Lincoln, St. Charles, St. Louis, and Warren; and the Illinois counties of Bond, Calhoun, Clinton, Jersey, Macoupin, Madison, Monroe and St. Clair. SOURCE: Chain Store Guide‚Äôs 2016 Grocery Industry Market Share Report Post-Dispatch Save-A-Lot revamps as rivals vie for market share By Lisa Brown St. Louis Post-Dispatch Lisa Brown Oct 7, 2016 (‚Ä¶) +5¬† Two Walmart smaller-format Neighborhood Market stores opened in St. Peters in early 2016.¬† Handout Christian Gooden ‚Ä¢ cgooden@post-dispatch.com FILE PHOTO: A customer leaves Save-A-Lot food retailer in Overland on Tuesday, July 28, 2015. Photo by Christian Gooden, cgooden@post-dispatch.com Laurie Skrivan FILE PHOTO: Save-A-Lot employees Paul Treece (left) and Sarah Krantz (right) hustle to load onions into bags for the families during the St. Louis Area Foodbank's mobile food bank Wednesday, September 19, 2012, in Jennings, Mo. Save-A-Lot and Good News Baptist Church members volunteered at the food bank. Photo by Laurie Skrivan, lskrivan@post-dispatch.com Buy Now Robert Cohen FILE PHOTO: Tanya Parker (center) of Beyond Housing's Rosie Shields Manor, a senior housing community, helps residents Sheila Tidwell (left) and Valerie Payne with their shopping at the Save-A-Lot in Pagedale on Tuesday, March 25, 2014. The nonprofit lured Save-A-Lot to open a store where the agency owns the land. Photo by Robert Cohen, rcohen@post-dispatch.com Buy Now Robert Cohen FILE PHOTO: Sheila Tidwell shops at the Save-A-Lot in Pagedale, located across a parking lot from her home in the senior community, Rosie Shields Manor on Tuesday, March 25, 2014. The nonprofit Beyond Housing lured Save-A-Lot to open a store where the agency owns the land. Photo by Robert Cohen, rcohen@post-dispatch.com As it faces a possible sale or spinoff, the Save-A-Lot grocery store chain is boosting the number of national brands on its shelves, remodeling to highlight fresh foods and adding stores. The changes underway at some of the discount chain‚Äôs 1,368 stores nationwide come as the Earth City-based grocer is poised to change ownership and as its discount chain rivals Wal-Mart and Ruler Foods are adding stores and services in the St. Louis region, vying for market share. Eden Prairie, Minn.-based Supervalu, which owns Save-A-Lot, is exploring spinning off Save-A-Lot as a stand-alone company or a sale of the chain amid increased competition and declines in prices for eggs, pork, beef and other foods. Reuters reported last week that Toronto private equity firm Onex Corp. was the leading bidder if Supervalu pursues a sale of Save-A-Lot, with a sale value of up to $1.8 billion. Supervalu is expected to announce Save-A-Lot‚Äôs fate soon, according to Reuters. The company did not respond to requests seeking comment. In a regulatory filing this summer, Save-A-Lot said if it‚Äôs spun off, its headquarters would remain in Earth City. Private label foods, which are sold under store brands, account for 60 percent of sales at Save-A-Lot‚Äôs corporate-owned stores and 55 percent at its licensee stores. Founded as a single store in Cahokia in 1977, the chain‚Äôs business model has centered on offering low-priced alternatives to national brands but it‚Äôs expanding its lineup of national brands. The company said this year that all of its corporate stores and most of its licensed stores recently started carrying 130 ‚Äúmust have‚Äù national brand items in a bid to attract and maintain new customers. Save-A-Lot‚Äôs private label offerings include maple syrup and biscuits sold under its own ‚ÄúMorning Delight‚Äù brand. ‚ÄúPrivate label branding at Save-A-Lot has no brand equity with consumers,‚Äù said Ajay Jain, a senior analyst at Pivitol Research Group in New York. To attract more brand-conscious customers, Save-A-Lot is carrying more national brands and consolidating its myriad private label offerings to one primary brand, America‚Äôs Choice, which it acquired earlier this year. ‚ÄúOver time, we expect that America‚Äôs Choice will become the predominant food private label brand in our stores as we seek to consolidate our private label brand offerings by reducing the number of private label brands that we offer while increasing brand recognition and enhancing brand equity,‚Äù the company said in the regulatory filing. Save-A-Lot‚Äôs current ads show an expanded array of national brands available, including Maxwell House coffee, Totino‚Äôs pizza rolls and Lay‚Äôs potato chips. ‚ÄúThe American consumer does appreciate and demand their brands,‚Äù Supervalu‚Äôs president and CEO Mark Gross told analysts at the RBC Capital Markets Consumer and Retail Conference in Boston in June, referring to Save-A-Lot‚Äôs changes. While it adds brands, Save-A-Lot also said it plans to open 75 new stores in fiscal 2017, and ‚Äúwe believe the United States can support more than 3,500 Save-A-Lot stores under our existing store concept and layout,‚Äù according to the filing. The grocer also is remodeling its stores to bring its produce departments closer to the front of each store, expanding its fresh cut meat offerings, adding more ethnic foods and expanding its frozen and smoked meat departments. ‚ÄúThe merchandising could use a shot in the arm,‚Äù Jain said of the remodels the chain is pursuing. ‚ÄúThe stores were pretty tired looking.‚Äù Changing landscape Save-A-Lot is under pressure from rivals that are also expanding their food options, including Wal-Mart, which has been growing its Walmart Neighborhood Markets chain nationally and locally. NOTES * Dollar Tree acquired Family Dollar in July 2015, boosting its local store count. ** Report defines St. Louis region as St. Louis and the Missouri counties of Jefferson, Lincoln, St. Charles, St. Louis, and Warren; and the Illinois counties of Bond, Calhoun, Clinton, Jersey, Macoupin, Madison, Monroe and St. Clair. SOURCE: Chain Store Guide‚Äôs 2016 Grocery Industry Market Share Report Post-Dispatch Walmart Neighborhood Markets have about 41,000 square feet of space, and the grocery stores have fresh produce, pharmacy, deli and bakery departments. That size makes them smaller than most Schnucks stores, but larger than Save-A-Lot‚Äôs average 17,000-square-foot store. At the Walmart Neighborhood Market at 45 Sutters Mill Road in St. Peters, customers can order groceries online and have them delivered curbside to their cars, beginning Nov. 9. Wal-Mart said it plans to have online order pickup available at 600 stores by the end of the year. +5¬† FILE PHOTO: Chris Krehmeyer, president and CEO of Beyond Housing, pushes a grocery cart holding Diamond Rhymes (center), 4, in 2010 to mark the grand opening of the Save-A-Lot grocery store in Pagedale. It was the first new grocery store for the area in forty years. Photo by John L. White | jwhite@post-dispatch.com Who's hired? Check our People in Business Meet the top midsized workplaces in St. Louis What's going up: Read the Building Blocks blog Get the Bottom Line from Nicklaus and Gallagher Combined, Walmart‚Äôs Supercenters, Neighborhood Markets and Sam‚Äôs Club stores have 28.7 percent market share of grocery sales in the St. Louis region, according to Chain Store Guide‚Äôs 2016 Grocery Industry Market Share Report, which reflects fiscal year 2015 sales. Included in Chain Store Guide‚Äôs definition of the St. Louis market are the Illinois counties of Bond, Calhoun, Clinton, Jersey, Macoupin, Madison, Monroe and St. Clair; and the Missouri counties of Jefferson, Lincoln, St. Charles, St. Louis, St. Louis city and Warren. In 2014, Wal-Mart‚Äôs local share totaled 28.8 percent. Wal-Mart may put the brakes on adding stores, however. The retailer said Thursday that it plans to slow down its store openings to focus on online sales, store remodels and tech initiatives. Maryland Heights-based Schnuck Markets Inc., the largest locally based, independently owned grocer, has 23.7 percent market share, a drop from 23.9 percent in 2014, according to Chain Store Guide. Supervalu‚Äôs Save-A-Lot chain and another chain it owns, Kirkwood-based Shop ‚Äôn Save, combined have 13.2 market share ‚Äî the report does not break down the figures for each chain. Chesterfield-based Dierbergs comes in fourth, with 10 percent market share. Other chains that are expanding include German-based Aldi, which opened its newest St. Louis area store in Shrewsbury this week and plans to open a location in Wentzville early next year. Aldi had 3.4 percent market share in St. Louis last year, down slightly from 3.6 percent. One of the biggest increases in local market share came from Cincinnati-based Kroger Co., which re-entered the St. Louis market under a subsidiary‚Äôs Ruler Foods brand in 2014. Ruler, which has added seven local stores in the past year, now has nine St. Louis area stores. Ruler Foods grew its market share in St. Louis to 3.3 percent in 2015, up from 1.9 percent a year earlier. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre constantly looking at sites,‚Äù Ruler Foods‚Äô executive director of merchandising, Mark Belleville, said of St. Louis. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre very happy with what is happening in the market and how customers are accepting us. We want to continue to grow.‚Äù About 85 percent of Ruler Foods‚Äô merchandise is private label, many under the Kroger brand. Belleville said Ruler Foods stocks Kroger-branded food items, which resonate with customers who remember when the chain had stores here in the mid-1980s. ‚ÄúThere are people who tell us it‚Äôs like an old friend coming home,‚Äù Belleville said.
